result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew J Stensven was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Defendant must attend and successfully complete an alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant is to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.   Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment, and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.   Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

 Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Attend and successfully complete anger management counseling, if agent deems appropriate.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea
Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

DA Gerald Fox appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody, with Attorney Sebion.  Parties have the revocation summary.  No corrections or changes noted.  No victim interests, per DA Fox.  Stipulation as to sentence credit as follows:  15CF74, credit for 115.  15CF151 and 15CF165, 72 days credit.  State recommended:  15CF74:  Count 1.  6 months jail.  Concurrent.  15CF74.  Count 2, concurrent 90 days.  Attorney Sebion says this is a joint recommendation.   Court ordered:  15CF74, Count 1:  6 months jail.  Count 2: 90 days jail, concurrent. Credit for 115 days.   15CF151:  6 months jail, concurrent.  Credit for 72 days.  15CF165:  6 months jail, concurrent.  Credit for 72 days.   Judgment for unpaid court ordered financial obligations.
ROAW and summary sent to Judge Becker electronically.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on June 20, 2016 at 10:00 am.

ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Poss.  Plead no contest to amended Count 1.  Count 2 dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties of the charge he plead to.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defendant understood.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of count 1.  Joint recommendation for  2 years probation.  Concurrent with current probation.    Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Seek and maintain employment.   The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions. AODA.  Defendant exercised his right to allocution.  Court ordered sentence withheld, 2 years probation.   Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.    Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.Seek and maintain employment.    The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by the COMPAS assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions. AODA. CC, plus DNA surcharge.    Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.  Subject to Random testing.  Anger management, if agent deems appropriate.

Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Attorney Poss explained waiver of time limits to the defendant.  Defendant does not object to waiving time limits.  Court questioned defendant on his understanding of the waiver of time limits for the preliminary hearing.  Defendant understood.  Court found that the defendant freely and intelligently waived the time limits for holding the preliminary hearing.
